title: Monolinear
content:
In [sans serif](http://web.archive.org/web/20141127072201/http:/typophile.com/wiki/sans%20serif) and [linear](http://web.archive.org/web/20141127072201/http:/typophile.com/wiki/linear) types, a [stroke](http://web.archive.org/web/20141127072201/http:/typophile.com/wiki/stroke) and [stem](http://web.archive.org/web/20141127072201/http:/typophile.com/wiki/stem) of constant width. Strict monolinear fonts have identical horizontal and vertical stroke width. Practical monolinear fonts have a vertical stroke slightly wider than their horizontal stroke width.

The best-known example of a monolinear type is [Futura](http://web.archive.org/web/20141127072201/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Futura) designed by [Paul Renner](http://web.archive.org/web/20141127072201/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Paul%20Renner). Also [Century](http://web.archive.org/web/20141127072201/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Century) and [Avenir](http://web.archive.org/web/20141127072201/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Avenir).
author: James Arboghast
